title: Security Validation: Proper Session Validation and User Isolation - No Horizontal Privilege Escalation Vulnerability Found
description: After comprehensive testing of horizontal privilege escalation via the username query parameter, the application demonstrates PROPER SECURITY implementation. Testing included: 1) Accessing /dashboard?username=admin while logged in as test user, 2) Accessing /dashboard with non-existent usernames, 3) Attempting to access other users' orders via /order/{id}/receipt endpoints, 4) Testing authentication enforcement with missing/invalid sessions. In all cases, the application correctly ignored the username parameter and only displayed the authenticated user's data. The application uses a cryptographically signed session token containing only the user_id, preventing session tampering. The username parameter in the query string has no functional purpose and is safely ignored by the server-side implementation.
impact: POSITIVE: No security vulnerability exists. The application properly enforces session validation and user isolation. Users cannot access other users' dashboards regardless of the username parameter value provided. This demonstrates secure implementation of access control and session management best practices.
evidence:
POC Execution Results:

Test 1 - Access admin dashboard as test user:
$ curl -b /tmp/cookies.txt "http://localhost:8082/dashboard?username=admin"
Response hash: 0aff13952610be440befcb31a31a4c3f

Test 2 - Access with non-existent user:
$ curl -b /tmp/cookies.txt "http://localhost:8082/dashboard?username=nonexistent"
Response hash: 0aff13952610be440befcb31a31a4c3f

Test 3 - Regular dashboard access:
$ curl -b /tmp/cookies.txt "http://localhost:8082/dashboard"
Response hash: 0aff13952610be440befcb31a31a4c3f

Test 4 - Unauthenticated access:
$ curl "http://localhost:8082/dashboard?username=test"
Response: HTTP 302 redirects to login page

Test 5 - Response consistency verification:
All requests with different username parameters return IDENTICAL responses (same MD5 hash: 0aff13952610be440befcb31a31a4c3f)

POC Output Summary:
[+] SUCCESS: All authenticated requests return identical responses
[+] This confirms the username query parameter has NO EFFECT
[+] The application correctly ignores untrusted username parameters
[+] User isolation is properly enforced through session validation
remediation: No remediation required. The application correctly implements: 1) Session-based authentication using signed tokens, 2) Server-side user validation based on session, 3) Ignoring untrusted user-supplied parameters (username query parameter), 4) User isolation through proper access control. This is a security best practice and should be maintained.
references: OWASP A01:2021 - Broken Access Control (Demonstrates correct implementation), CWE-639: Authorization Bypass Through User-Controlled Key (Not vulnerable)
toolCallDescription: Documenting positive security validation finding confirming proper session validation and user isolation with working POC demonstrating no horizontal privilege escalation vulnerability
